channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Lawfare editor Benjamin Wittes reacts to the James Comey indictment
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Lawfare editor in chief Benjamin Wittes, a friend of James Comey, about the former FBI director's indictment on charges of obstructing justice and making a false statement to Congress.

item.title: Former FBI Director James Comey indicted on criminal charges
item.description: The Justice Department indicted former FBI Director James Comey Thursday, after President Trump demanded prosecutors speed up their investigation into one of his most prominent critics.

item.title: Sen. Tim Kaine reacts to the indictment of former FBI Director James Comey
item.description: NPR speaks with Sen. Tim Kaine, D-Va., following the Trump administration's indictment of former FBI Director James Comey.

item.title: I remember doing the Time Warp: The 'Rocky Horror Picture Show' turns 50
item.description: Fifty years ago, on Sept. 26, 1975, The Rocky Horror Picture Show flopped at the U.S. box office — then became the longest-running theatrical release in history.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The Justice Department indicts former FBI Director James Comey, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth calls top military officials to meet, Trump threatens large-scale layoffs if government shuts down.

item.title: Inside the Department of Homeland Security's first major career fair amid hiring push
item.description: NPR attended a career fair in Utah where the Department of Homeland Security was looking to boost its ranks.

item.title: New documentary celebrates the success of women-led music festival Lilith Fair
item.description: "Lilith Fair: Building a Mystery" recalls the success of the woman-led music festival created by singer Sarah McLachlan. McLachlan and documentarian Ally Pankiw talk about the film.

item.title: Amazon agrees to pay $2.5 billion to settle U.S. lawsuit over Prime program
item.description: Millions of Amazon shoppers might be getting a refund after the company agreed to pay $2.5 billion to settle a lawsuit over its Prime membership program.

item.title: Back-to-school costs are climbing. How one school district is easing the burden
item.description: Back-to-school supplies are getting more expensive for parents and teachers. The team from "The Indicator" explains what one school district is doing to address the issue.

item.title: How escalator safety mechanisms work — and why they cause machines to stop
item.description: President Trump called his escalator mishap at the United Nations "sabotage." The U.N. says the White House team triggered a safety mechanism. We asked two people who work on escalators to explain.
